elements.content: Six new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, {[Cd­(BPBP)0.5(hfipbb)]·0.5DMF} n (1), {[Zn­(BPBP)0.5(hfipbb)]} n (2), {[Co­(BPBP)0.5(hfipbb)·0.5DMF]} n (3), {[Zn­(BPBP)­(trans-chdc)]·H2O} n (4), {[Zn2(BPBP)­(4,4′-sdb)2]} n (5), and {[Zn2(BPBP)­(oba)2]·H2O·DMA} n (6) (BPBP = 5,5′-bis­(4-pyridyl)-2,2′-bithiophene, H2hfipbb = 4,4′-(hexaﬂuoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid), trans-H2chdc = trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, 4,4′- H2sdb = 4,4′-sulfonyldicarboxylic acid, H2oba = 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoic acid), DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide), have been hydrothermally synthesized. These compounds were characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis and X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Compounds 1–3 are isostructural and display 3D 2-fold interpenetrating frameworks with rare {44.610.8} mab topologies. Compound 4 exhibits a 3D diamond-type (dia, 66) framework of 6-fold interpenetration. Compound 5 shows a 2D network with {44·62}-sql topology, which consists of 1D [Zn2(4,4′-sdb)2] n chains. Compound 6 possesses a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D framework with 6-connected {412·63} pcu topology. Magnetic studies reveal that compound 3 exhibits antiferromagnetic behavior. Thermal stabilities for 1–6 and photoluminescence properties of the compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 have been examined in solid states at room temperature. Furthermore, the UV–vis absorption spectra and optical energy gap of 3 were also investigated.

elements.content:
Six new MOFs based on 5,5′-bis­(4-pyridyl)-2,2′-bithiophene (BPBP) and dicarboxylates have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized in detail.

Introduction

In the last two decades, great attention has been paid to the design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) not only for their fascinating variety of architectures, but also for their promising applications in gas adsorption and separation, magnetism, sensing of target molecules, catalysis, luminescence, and so on. It is well-known that applications rely heavily on the structures, so the synthesis of desirable structural and functional MOFs is one hot research area now. Compared with traditional properties of MOFs above-mentioned, the photoelectric properties are not well investigated. The conjugated organic polymers such as polythiophenes are natural semiconductors with tunable band gaps and good hole transport properties. So, the polythiophene may be an excellent candidate for assembling novel optoelectrochemical MOFs. Though a small number of MOFs containing electron-donating bithiophene dicarboxylates as ligands have been reported, the bithiophene with different N-containing heterocycles has seldom been employed for the synthesis of MOFs. Considering all of these above-mentioned, we choose 5,5′-bis­(4-pyridyl)-2,2′-bithiophene (BPBP) as an organic linker to connect divalent transitional-metal ions (Zn, Cd, and Co) to get microporous coordination polymers.

Introduction

In the last two decades, great attention has been paid to the design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) not only for their fascinating variety of architectures, but also for their promising applications in gas adsorption and separation, magnetism, sensing of target molecules, catalysis, luminescence, and so on. It is well-known that applications rely heavily on the structures, so the synthesis of desirable structural and functional MOFs is one hot research area now. Compared with traditional properties of MOFs above-mentioned, the photoelectric properties are not well investigated. The conjugated organic polymers such as polythiophenes are natural semiconductors with tunable band gaps and good hole transport properties. So, the polythiophene may be an excellent candidate for assembling novel optoelectrochemical MOFs. Though a small number of MOFs containing electron-donating bithiophene dicarboxylates as ligands have been reported, the bithiophene with different N-containing heterocycles has seldom been employed for the synthesis of MOFs. Considering all of these above-mentioned, we choose 5,5'-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,2'-bithiophene (BPBP) as an organic linker to connect divalent transitional-metal ions (Zn, Cd, and Co) to get microporous coordination polymers.

elements.content: In this work, six new MOFs based on the BPBP, H2hfipbb, trans-H2chdc, 4,4′-H2sdb, and H2oba ligands (Scheme ), namely {[Cd­(BPBP)0.5(hfipbb)]·0.5DMF} n (1), {[Zn­(BPBP)0.5(hfipbb)]} n (2), {[Co­(BPBP)0.5(hfipbb)·0.5DMF]} n (3), {[Zn­(BPBP)­(trans-chdc)]·H2O} n (4), {[Zn2(BPBP)­(4,4′-sdb)2]} n (5), and {[Zn2(BPBP)­(oba)2]·H2O·DMA } n (6), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Their structures are characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, X-ray crystallography, and X-ray powder diffraction. The crystal structures and topological analyses are studied in detail. In addition, the optical band gaps, photoluminescence, magnetic character, and thermal properties are also investigated and discussed.

elements.clean_text: 1  N-Containing BPBP Ligand and Dicarboxylate Ligands

elements.content: All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. BPBP ligand was prepared according to the documented procedures. IR absorption spectra were recorded in the range 4000–400 cm–1 on a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets. C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 K·min–1 by using a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer. Solid-state luminescent spectra were recorded with a SHIMAZU VF-320 X-ray fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were collected at room temperature using a Shimadzu UV-3600 double monochromator spectrophotometer, and BaSO4 was used as a 100% reflectance standard for all materials. Temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility was obtained on polycrystalline samples using a MPMS XL-7 SQUID magnetometer under an applied field of 2000 Oe over the temperature range of 1.8–300 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. BPBP ligand was prepared according to the documented procedures. IR absorption spectra were recorded in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets. C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 K⋅min-1 by using a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer. Solid-state luminescent spectra were recorded with a SHIMAZU VF-320 X-ray fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra were collected at room temperature using a Shimadzu UV-3600 double monochromator spectrophotometer, and BaSO4 was used as a 100% reflectance standard for all materials. Temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility was obtained on polycrystalline samples using a MPMS XL-7 SQUID magnetometer under an applied field of 2000 Oe over the temperature range of 1.8-300 K.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·6H2O (30.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), BPBP (16.0 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) (39.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of DMF/H2O (1:3, v/v). The final mixture was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL) under autogenous pressure and heated at 100 °C for 3 days. Yellow needle crystals of 38.5 mg (yield of 55% based on Cd) were collected. Anal. Calcd for C27.5H17.5CdF6N1.5O4.5S: C, 47.22%; H, 2.52%; N, 3.00%. Found: C, 47.18%; H, 2.58%; N, 3.05%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3408­(w), 1627(s), 1607­(vs), 1555­(w), 1436­(w), 1399(s), 1252­(m), 1212­(m), 1172(s), 1021­(w), 969­(w), 929­(w), 795­(m), 725­(m), 495­(w).

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data of 1–6 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted onto thin glass fibers. X-ray diffraction data of these compounds were collected on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Structure solutions were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structures and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The distribution of peaks in the channels of 1, 3, 4, and 6 were chemically featureless to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contributions of the electron density by the remaining DMF in 1, 3, the water molecules in 4 and DMA, and the water molecules in 6 were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The numbers of solvent molecules were obtained by element analyses. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in the (Table S1). A semiempirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS.

X-ray diffraction data of 1-6 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted onto thin glass fibers. X-ray diffraction data of these compounds were collected on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Structure solutions were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structures and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL  using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The distribution of peaks in the channels of 1, 3, 4, and 6 were chemically featureless to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contributions of the electron density by the remaining DMF in 1, 3, the water molecules in 4 and DMA, and the water molecules in 6 were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The numbers of solvent molecules were obtained by element analyses. Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that 1–3 are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic crystal system with P2/c space group. Hence, only the structure of 1 is described in detail and the structure description of crystals 2 and 3 can be found in the (Figure S7 and S8). X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that 1 is a 3D supramolecular architecture with 3-fold interpenetration. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Cd­(II) cation, a half BPBP ligand, and one deprotonated 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid). As shown in Figure a, each Cd­(II) is square-pyramidally coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four symmetrical hfipbb ligands at the basal positions and one N atom from one BPBP ligand at the apical position. The Cd–N bond distance is 2.233(2) Å, and the Cd–O bond distances vary in the range of 2.216(2)–2.243(2) Å, which are normal bond distances found in other Cd complexes. Two crystallographically equivalent Cd­(II) cations are bridged by four carboxylate groups adopting a bis-bidentate coordination mode to generate a dinuclear Cd­(II) “paddlewheel” secondary building unit (SBU) with a Cd···Cd distance of 3.096(4) Å. This [Cd2(CO2)4] unit is interesting and rarely observed in other coordination compounds. Interestingly, the paddlewheel is bridged by hfipbb ligands to form a 2D undulating (4, 4) network with rhomb-like windows (Figure b). The diagonals of the rhombic windows are about 15.266 × 23.774 Å2. As depicted in Figure c, an interesting feature in this network is the presence of two kinds of helical chains, where the left-handed and right-handed 1D helical chains coexist and array alternately by sharing the paddlewheel SBUs. The large enough rhomboid voids of each layer allow one layer to interpenetrate with another in a parallel interpenetrated 2D → 2D architecture, in which interwoven bilayers with 1D double helical channels are formed (Figure d). These interpenetrated helical 2D layers are further connected by the BPBP ligands to form a 3D coordination polymer network (Figure e). The Cd···Cd distance separated by the BPBP ligand is 19.0718(13) Å.

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2/c. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn­(II) cation, two halve of a BPBP ligand, and two halve of a deprotonated trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid. The local coordination geometry around the Zn­(II) cation is depicted in Figure a. The Zn­(II) cation adopts a distorted tetrahedron geometry defined by two oxygen atoms [Zn–O = 1.953(2) Å] from two symmetrical trans-chdc anions and two N atoms [Zn–N = 2.060(2) Å] from two symmetrical BPBP ligands. The Zn–O/N bond distances fall in the normal range found in other Zn complexes. The carboxylate groups of the trans-chdc ligands link the Zn­(II) cation centers into an infinite 1D zig-zag chain, as shown in Figure b, which contains a Zn···Zn separation of 10.700(9) Å and a Zn–Zn–Zn angle of 126.430(1)°. Such 1D zig-zag chains are further linked by the BPBP ligands, leading to the formation of a 3D framework (Figure c and d). A better insight into the nature of this 3D framework can be provided by a topology analysis. The 3D structure of 4 can be clarified as a classical 4-connected diamond (dia) lattice by considering Zn­(II) cations as the 4-connected nodes and all ligands as the 2-connected spacers (Figure e). Notably, the large channel in a single framework has an approximate pore size of 18.82 Å × 26.16 Å, which allows the other five identical 3D single frameworks to penetrate and, thus, affords a 6-fold interpenetrating architecture. Hence, the large pore void spaces of a single net have been reduced significantly. Upon interpenetration, the crystal only retains an effective void volume of 335.1 Å3 per unit cell, which is 23.6% of the crystal volume, calculated by PLATON analysis. Therefore, the whole structure can thus be represented as a dia topology (with the Schläfli symbol {66}) (Figure f).

elements.content: The crystal structure determination reveals that compound 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system P21/c. As shown in Figure a, there are two crystallographically independent Zn­(II) cations, one BPBP ligand, and two deprotonated 4,4′-sulfonyldicarboxylic acids. Each Zn­(II) cation is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two symmetrical 4,4′-sdb ligands and one nitrogen atom from one BPBP ligand, giving a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry, where the nitrogen atom locates at the top of the square pyramid and the four carboxylate oxygen atoms construct the bottom. The bond lengths of Zn–O and Zn–N are 2.030(5)–2.056­(5) Å and 2.023(7) Å, which are all similar to those found in other Zn­(II) complexes. The completely deprotonated 4,4′-sdb ligand shows a bidentate coordination mode. Pairs of Zn­(II) cations are joined by two symmetrical 4,4′-sdb ligands to generate a dinuclear Zn­(II) “paddlewheel” type secondary building unit (SBU) with a Zn···Zn separation of 3.006(3) Å. These paddlewheel SBUs are further bridged through the second terminal carboxylate group of the symmetrical 4,4′-sdb ligands into a 1D chain with a 10.25 Å × 13.75 Å loop (Figure b). Then the BPBP ligands join all infinite 1D chains into a 2D layer with a Zn···Zn distance of 18.830(2) Å (Figure c). If the SBUs [Zn2(CO2)4] are considered as 4-connected nodes, and 4,4′-sdb and BPBP ligands are considered as linkers, the 2D network can be simplified to an sql net with Schläfli symbol {44·62} (Figure d). Furthermore, the packing diagram clearly exposes that the neighboring 2D networks are parallel with a separation of 7.32 Å and stack alternatively with ···ABAB··· mode, as depicted in Figure e.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound 6 crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system, space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Zn­(II) cations, one BPBP ligand, and two deprotonated 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoic acids) (Figure a). The two carboxylate groups of the oba ligand adopt different coordination modes: one carboxylate group takes a bismonodentate coordination mode to bridge two Zn centers while the other carboxylate group chelates in a bidentate mode. Both Zn­(II) cations are five-coordinated and possess a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry surrounded by four oxygen atoms belonging to three different oba ligands and one nitrogen atom from the BPBP ligand. The Zn–O bond distances vary in the range of 1.946(3)–2.346­(4) Å, and the Zn–N bond distances vary in the range of 2.048(4)–2.054(4) Å. When the connections via the BPBP ligands are ignored, the Zn­(II) cations are linked through the oba ligands to form 2D layers (Figure b). In addition, there exist weak π···π stacking interactions (centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.526(3) Å) among adjacent aromatic cycles of oba ligands, which further stabilize the 2D layers. Such resulting layers are further connected by BPBP ligands, leading to the formation of a 3D framework (Figure c and d). From the viewpoint of structural topology, each dinuclear Zn­(II) unit can be viewed as a 6-connected node; thus, compound 6 represents a {412·63} α-Po pcu topology by using BPBP and oba ligands as linkers (Figure e). Because of the large void volume in the single net in 6, three independent equivalent frameworks interpenetrate each other to keep their stabilities of the whole structure, which directly leads to the formation of a 3-fold interpenetrated final framework (Figure f). PLATON analysis gives the free void volume ratio of 23.7% in compound 6.

elements.content: The UV–vis absorption spectra of BPBP, H2hfipbb, and 3 were carried out in the crystalline state at room temperature (). The H2hfipbb and BPBP ligands exhibit absorption bands in the ranges of 270–300 and 450–580 nm, respectively, which can be ascribed to π → π* and n → π* transitions of the ligands, respectively. The lower energy band from 510 to 665 nm for 3 can be attributed to the spin-allowed d–d transition of the d7 (Co2+) cation. To explore the semiconductivity, the diffuse reflectance data is transformed into a Kubelka–Munk function to obtain their band gaps (E g). As shown in , the band gap of BPBP is approximately 2.39 eV, which exhibits the nature of semiconductivity. The E g value assessed from the steep absorption edge is 2.26 eV for 3, which indicates that compound 3 is a potential wide gap semiconductor material.

UV-Visible Spectra

The UV-vis absorption spectra of BPBP, H2hfipbb, and 3 were carried out in the crystalline state at room temperature (). The H2hfipbb and BPBP ligands exhibit absorption bands in the ranges of 270-300 and 450-580 nm, respectively, which can be ascribed to π → π* and n → π* transitions of the ligands, respectively. The lower energy band from 510 to 665 nm for 3 can be attributed to the spin-allowed d-d transition of the d7 (Co2+) cation. To explore the semiconductivity, the diffuse reflectance data is transformed into a Kubelka-Munk function to obtain their band gaps (E g). As shown in , the band gap of BPBP is approximately 2.39 eV, which exhibits the nature of semiconductivity. The E g value assessed from the steep absorption edge is 2.26 eV for 3, which indicates that compound 3 is a potential wide gap semiconductor material.

elements.content: The luminescent properties of MOFs with d10 metal centers have attracted great interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The solid-state luminescence of free ligands BPBP, H2hfipbb, trans-H2chdc, 4,4′-H2sdb, and H2oba and compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 are investigated at room temperature, as shown in Figure S10 and Table S2 of the . The main emission peaks of the BPBP, H2hfipbb, 4,4′-H2sdb, and H2oba were observed at 548 nm (λex = 430 nm), 325 nm (λex = 290 nm), 344 nm (λex = 296 nm), and 317 nm (λex = 276 nm), which can be assigned to the π* → n or π* → π transitions. The emission peaks at 530 nm (λex = 394 nm) in 1, 541 nm (λex = 396 nm) in 2, 556 nm (λex = 392 nm) in 4, 532 nm (λex = 398 nm) in 5, and 536 nm (λex = 400 nm) in 6 are similar to that of the free BPBP ligand. Therefore, the emission bands of compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 can be mainly attributed to the intraligand (BPBP) emissions. Compared to the free BPBP ligand, the emission band of 1, 2, 5, and 6 is 18 nm, 7 nm, 16 nm, and 12 nm blue-shifted and the emission band of 4 is 8 nm red-shifted, respectively.

Luminescent Properties

The luminescent properties of MOFs with d10 metal centers have attracted great interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. The solid-state luminescence of free ligands BPBP, H2hfipbb, trans-H2chdc, 4,4'-H2sdb, and H2oba and compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 are investigated at room temperature, as shown in Figure S10 and Table S2 of the . The main emission peaks of the BPBP, H2hfipbb, 4,4'-H2sdb, and H2oba were observed at 548 nm (λex = 430 nm), 325 nm (λex = 290 nm), 344 nm (λex = 296 nm), and 317 nm (λex = 276 nm), which can be assigned to the π* → n or π* → π transitions. The emission peaks at 530 nm (λex = 394 nm) in 1, 541 nm (λex = 396 nm) in 2, 556 nm (λex = 392 nm) in 4, 532 nm (λex = 398 nm) in 5, and 536 nm (λex = 400 nm) in 6 are similar to that of the free BPBP ligand. Therefore, the emission bands of compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 can be mainly attributed to the intraligand (BPBP) emissions. Compared to the free BPBP ligand, the emission band of 1, 2, 5, and 6 is 18 nm, 7 nm, 16 nm, and 12 nm blue-shifted and the emission band of 4 is 8 nm red-shifted, respectively.

elements.content: In order to check whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out for 1–6 at room temperature. As shown in Figures S11–S16 (), the peak positions of the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns are in agreement with each other, demonstrating that the bulk synthesized materials and the measured single crystals are the same.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and Thermal Analysis

In order to check whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were carried out for 1-6 at room temperature. As shown in Figures S11-S16 (), the peak positions of the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns are in agreement with each other, demonstrating that the bulk synthesized materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability of these compounds, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out (). The TGA curve of compound 1 shows a weight loss of 5.23% (calcd 5.65%) in the 157–390 °C range attributed to the loss of a half uncoordinated DMF molecule; then the decomposition of compound 1 starts. For compound 2, which does not contain guest molecules, it is decomposed quickly after 434 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. The TGA curve of 3 exhibits an initial weight loss from 168 to 425 °C, with the observed weight loss of 5.29% (calcd 5.66%) corresponding to the escape of a half uncoordinated DMF molecule. After that an additional weight loss of 80.35% up to 600 °C may be attributed to the gradual release of coordinated BPBP and hfipbb ligands. The remaining weight can be attributed to the formation of Co2O3 (obsd 14.36%, calcd 12.84%). For compound 4, the preliminary weight loss of approximately 2.98% beginning at 135 to 317 °C is attributed to the loss of a water molecule (calcd 3.14%). The following weight loss may be attributed to the gradual release of the BPBP and trans-chdc ligands ended at 638 °C with retention of weight of 14.28% (calcd 14.18%), corresponding to ZnO. The TGA study of compound 5 shows no weight loss from room temperature to 320 °C, indicating the better thermal stability of the framework. Above 320 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed which is attributed to the burning of the organic ligands. Compound 6 shows continuous weight losses of the lattice DMA and H2O followed by the decomposition of organic parts from 125 to 627 °C. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of ZnO (obsd 15.24%, calcd 15.23%).

elements.content: The magnetic measurement was performed on polycrystalline samples of 3 in an applied field of 2000 Oe in the temperature range of 1.8–300 K. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 3 in the form of χ M T versus T is displayed in Figure . As discussed before, compound 3 contains a dimeric paddlewheel cluster of Co­(II) ions. The χ M T value at room temperature is 4.52 cm3 K mol–1, which is larger than the expected spin-only value of 3.875 cm3 K mol–1 for two Co­(II) ions (S = 3/2). Upon cooling, χ M T decreases continuously and reaches 0.047 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K. The curve indicates the typical antiferromagnetic and spin–orbit coupling interactions present in the compound 3.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of Compound 3 

The magnetic measurement was performed on polycrystalline samples of 3 in an applied field of 2000 Oe in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 3 in the form of χ M  T versus T is displayed in Figure . As discussed before, compound 3 contains a dimeric paddlewheel cluster of Co(II) ions. The χ M  T value at room temperature is 4.52 cm3 K mol-1, which is larger than the expected spin-only value of 3.875 cm3 K mol-1 for two Co(II) ions (S = 3/2). Upon cooling, χ M  T decreases continuously and reaches 0.047 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K. The curve indicates the typical antiferromagnetic and spin-orbit coupling interactions present in the compound 3.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized six new compounds by the self-assembly of BPBP, H2hfipbb, trans-H2chdc, 4,4′- H2sdb, and H2oba ligands and Cd­(II), Zn­(II), and Co­(II) cations under hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1–3 show a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D metal–organic framework with {44·610·8} mab topology. Compound 4 exhibits 6-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks with {66} dia topology. Compound 5 is a 2D network composed of chains of [Zn2(4,4′-sdb)2] with {44·62}-sql topology. Compound 6 reveals 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks with {412·63} pcu topology. The thermal stabilities for 1–6 and photoluminescence properties of compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 have been examined. Furthermore, the optical absorption spectra of 3 imply that it is a potential wide gap semiconductor material. Moreover, magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that compound 3 exhibits antiferromagnetic coupling interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized six new compounds by the self-assembly of BPBP, H2hfipbb, trans-H2chdc, 4,4'- H2sdb, and H2oba ligands and Cd(II), Zn(II), and Co(II) cations under hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1-3 show a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D metal-organic framework with {44⋅610⋅8} mab topology. Compound 4 exhibits 6-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks with {66} dia topology. Compound 5 is a 2D network composed of chains of [Zn2(4,4'-sdb)2] with {44⋅62}-sql topology. Compound 6 reveals 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks with {412⋅63} pcu topology. The thermal stabilities for 1-6 and photoluminescence properties of compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 have been examined. Furthermore, the optical absorption spectra of 3 imply that it is a potential wide gap semiconductor material. Moreover, magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that compound 3 exhibits antiferromagnetic coupling interaction.

cln_elements.content:
To investigate the thermal stability of these compounds, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out (). The TGA curve of compound 1 shows a weight loss of 5.23% (calcd 5.65%) in the 157–390 °C range attributed to the loss of a half uncoordinated DMF molecule; then the decomposition of compound 1 starts. For compound 2, which does not contain guest molecules, it is decomposed quickly after 434 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. The TGA curve of 3 exhibits an initial weight loss from 168 to 425 °C, with the observed weight loss of 5.29% (calcd 5.66%) corresponding to the escape of a half uncoordinated DMF molecule. After that an additional weight loss of 80.35% up to 600 °C may be attributed to the gradual release of coordinated BPBP and hfipbb ligands. The remaining weight can be attributed to the formation of Co2O3 (obsd 14.36%, calcd 12.84%). For compound 4, the preliminary weight loss of approximately 2.98% beginning at 135 to 317 °C is attributed to the loss of a water molecule (calcd 3.14%). The following weight loss may be attributed to the gradual release of the BPBP and trans-chdc ligands ended at 638 °C with retention of weight of 14.28% (calcd 14.18%), corresponding to ZnO. The TGA study of compound 5 shows no weight loss from room temperature to 320 °C, indicating the better thermal stability of the framework. Above 320 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed which is attributed to the burning of the organic ligands. Compound 6 shows continuous weight losses of the lattice DMA and H2O followed by the decomposition of organic parts from 125 to 627 °C. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of ZnO (obsd 15.24%, calcd 15.23%).

Magnetic Properties of Compound <bold>3</bold>

The magnetic measurement was performed on polycrystalline samples of 3 in an applied field of 2000 Oe in the temperature range of 1.8–300 K. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 3 in the form of χ M T versus T is displayed in Figure . As discussed before, compound 3 contains a dimeric paddlewheel cluster of Co­(II) ions. The χ M T value at room temperature is 4.52 cm3 K mol–1, which is larger than the expected spin-only value of 3.875 cm3 K mol–1 for two Co­(II) ions (S = 3/2). Upon cooling, χ M T decreases continuously and reaches 0.047 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K. The curve indicates the typical antiferromagnetic and spin–orbit coupling interactions present in the compound 3.

To investigate the thermal stability of these compounds, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out (). The TGA curve of compound 1 shows a weight loss of 5.23% (calcd 5.65%) in the 157-390 °C range attributed to the loss of a half uncoordinated DMF molecule; then the decomposition of compound 1 starts. For compound 2, which does not contain guest molecules, it is decomposed quickly after 434 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. The TGA curve of 3 exhibits an initial weight loss from 168 to 425 °C, with the observed weight loss of 5.29% (calcd 5.66%) corresponding to the escape of a half uncoordinated DMF molecule. After that an additional weight loss of 80.35% up to 600 °C may be attributed to the gradual release of coordinated BPBP and hfipbb ligands.
